history.content: Don't be fooled by the homework. The exams are much, much harder. Also the best way to prepare for them is by taking exams from previous semesters.

children.subject:
I basically lived at office hours and labs. There you will receive a lot of quality help and you have the opportunity to make a lot of new friends. 

YouTube has a lot of past midterm and final walkthroughs. Go through those.

Make sure u take a bunch of practice exams from RECENT prior years before an exam (I would honestly suggest 5-7). 61A exams tend to repeat similar style questions so I would suggest the following strategy at least 1 week before an exam:

1) Take heavy notes on every section u have covered till that point. Even if it's midterm 2 and u already have notes from midterm 1, still take those notes again.
2) Print out all the tests you plan to take and take all but the two most recent of them. After each exam, grade them and for EACH question you get wrong write at least one note on a seperate page on how to crack that style of problem (like a step by step "look at this" "pay attention to that" thing).
3) Copy a summarized version of ur notes on ur cheat sheet(s) and leave a section to copy down the notes u wrote specific to ur mistakes on a test.
4) The night before the exam and perhaps the morning of the exam, take those last two tests and make slight adjustments to ur cheat sheet accordingly.

This strategy really helped me out specifically for 61A. It's still helpful for 61B but not much with 70 cause 61A and 61B material doesn't really change much over time (but in 61b the professor matters while in 61A all tests are good).

If you don't have any coding experience, there's actually a course that's I'm running for the department over the summer you might find helpful. Course is taught in Ruby which is very similar to Python (language used in 61A), and I'll also be going over things like GitHub and be available for questions in general all throughout the summer. It's all remote and you set your own pace, so feel free to sign up here.

Attend all the labs and lectures live (even though they are webcasted) so that you can ask questions. Also, don't be afraid to ask questions. Chances are, someone else is wondering the same thing but afraid to ask.

If you already happen to know any CS or Python, we've developed a couple of projects (Rock, Paper, Scissors, 2048, and an AI mini project extension to RPS) that are good lead ups to CS61A projects.

I would highly recommend 2048, as its calibrated at a difficulty that is just below what Hog (61A's first project) requires of you, and gets you very comfortable with syntax. There's a lot of targeted help that helps you build the critical thinking required to synthesize code entirely on your own as well! 

Here's the spec with setup directions within included! 

https://goo.gl/34kNbl

history.content: Preparation, tips and tricks to success are much appreciated.
history.subject: CS61A Summer
